source.c03f081e:
train['date_field'] = pd.to_datetime(train['instock_date']).map(lambda x: str(x).split("T")[0].split(" ")[0]).values
train['time_field'] = pd.to_datetime(train['instock_date']).map(lambda x: str(x).split("T")[0].split(" ")[1]).values
train.drop('instock_date', axis=1, inplace=True)
source.b3d66e56:
test['date_field'] = pd.to_datetime(test['instock_date']).map(lambda x: str(x).split("T")[0].split(" ")[0]).values
test['time_field'] = pd.to_datetime(test['instock_date']).map(lambda x: str(x).split("T")[0].split(" ")[1]).values
test.drop('instock_date', axis=1, inplace=True)

source.2d805cf2:
## Introduction to Auto_ViML
We are going to try to use Auto_ViML on this data set and see what rank we get. The github for Auto_ViML is located here:
https://github.com/AutoViML/Auto_ViML

The way to use Auto_VIML is to install it first using this command:
pip install autoviml
source.fcbf3bd5: Next we import the autoviml library and send in the train, test and sample submission data frames
